Boloria selene is found across Europe and Asia, inhabiting a range of habitats, including grasslands, heathlands, and woodland edges. The larvae feed on various violet species, including Viola riviniana and Viola canina, while the adults primarily nectar on flowers such as bramble, knapweed, and thistles.

This butterfly species is known for its adaptability and can thrive in both natural and managed landscapes, though it is sensitive to habitat loss and fragmentation. Conservation efforts aimed at preserving and restoring suitable habitats are important for the continued survival of the small pearl-bordered fritillary.
